div.p: Greetings in the Lord. The reason I did not respond to your recent letters, your reverence, was not due to any other cause, reverend father in Christ, than that they did not particularly require a response and I had nothing to write. Now, since a broad occasion and subject have been presented to me, I did not wish to delay the duty of writing any longer, lest I fall into the suspicion of neglected friendship with your reverence, which nothing more desirable could have happened to me.

I indicated to your reverence in my recent letters the reason why I was expelled by the people of Memmingen, namely because I refused to subscribe to that insidious confession or rather inquisition, in which the bodily presence of Christ in the supper and the eating and the monstrous notion of ubiquity are established and defended.
However, all the ministers both in the city and in the countryside subscribed, although one of the urban ministers, Eusebius Cleber, strongly opposed it and would have gladly prevented it, when...
